Award.AwardTitle: Design Principles for the Growth of High-quality Binary and Ternary Tin Oxides
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Description: Metal oxides play important roles in many critical applications such as photovoltaics, gas sensors and coatings for architectural glass. These applications require that thin oxide films be doped with small amounts of a different chemical element that improves the electrical conductivity of the film without changing its structure. For example, fluorine-doped tin oxide is used as an electrically conductive coating on glass in photovoltaic cells and in gas sensors. When tin oxide combines with an equal amount of barium oxide, a ceramic compound known as barium stannate forms. It has a more complex structure known as a perovskite, and its properties are extremely dependent on the perfection of the film. Initial experiments on barium stannate demonstrate remarkable electrical conductivities that can enable the development of a new class of microelectronics based on metal oxides. Depositing films with exact elemental ratios that are free of defects is difficult. This research studies the fundamental factors controlling the deposition of high quality tin oxide and barium stannate films. An important broader impact of this combined experimental and computational research is the production of videos that can be used to explain to students and the general public the events involved in the deposition processes.

Technical Description: Through a combination of experimental and theoretical/computational techniques, the researchers are identifying fundamental factors at the atomic and molecular level of detail that influence the rates and quality of crystal growth in binary and ternary tin oxides. Mechanistic knowledge gained from this work is aiding in the design of new molecular precursors and deposition processes. In addition, a separate chemometric approach offers a potentially powerful tool for rapid in-silico screening of alternative precursors with the goal of prioritizing experiments to focus on molecular precursors having a high likelihood of utility. An initial group of six tin precursors, including metal alkyls, amides and nitrates, is being used to deposit tin oxides in an ultrahigh vacuum reactor. Growth rates, measured in situ by using time-dependent intensity oscillations in the reflection high energy electron diffraction peaks, are studied as a function of substrate temperature, precursor and oxygen pressure, aiming to elucidate the deposition kinetics to be used as the basis for designing depositions of ternary tin oxides having the perovskite structure. In these depositions, molecular precursors are used as the tin source and effusion cells are used as sources for the group-two elements with the ultimate goal to understand the underlying design principles for chemical precursors that lead to self-regulating stoichiometry control.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
The compositional spectrum of metal oxide compounds results in a remarkable diversity of physical and chemical properties that leads to their application in many electronic, optical and magnetic and sensing devices. Metal oxides having the generic perovskite formula ABO3, where A and B are metals ions that typically exist in the +2 and +4 oxidation states, respectively, exhibit high temperature stability and electronic properties that make them candidates for future transistor and related devices. Such applications demand the functional metal oxides be deposited as thin films and have carefully controlled compositions and electronic conductivity. This research focused on films in which the element tin was one of the metals and led to the discovery that the organotin precursor, hexamethylditin (HMDT), allows for exquisite control of the metal composition in perovskites, BaSnO3 and SrSnO3, and in their doped analogs. The accurate stoichiometry control and high quality of the films led to record high electrical conductivities.

The films were deposited using a process known as hybrid molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) that involves the use of a molecular tin precursors in place of atomic tin vapor as is typically used in MBE processes. To better understand the impact of molecular structure on the deposition process, a series of closely related tin organometallics were compared using both experimental and computational methods. The computational research used quantum chemical methods to calculate the thermochemical properties of tetramethyltin (TMT) and HMDT and established that in the gas phase the equilibrium composition at different temperatures of the starting precursor and up to 68 fragments were similar suggesting the impact of chemistry depends on the kinetics of reactions at the surface of the growing film. Experimental kinetics for the deposition of SnO2 were compared for TMT, HMDT and tetraethyltin (TET), and the figure shows the growth rates as a function of temperature. All three precursors exhibit reaction-limited and flux-limited growth regimes, however, TET also shows a diminishing growth rate at higher temperatures. The positive effect that HMDT has on the hybrid MBE deposition of BaSnO3 and SrSnO3 was suggested to result from the relative weakness of the tin-tin bond, which leads more readily to tin radicals.

A critical broader impact of the program involved educating and training individuals who have entered or will soon enter the science and engineering workforce. This program contributed to the development of five people. Two students completed their PhD. Two additional students are expected to complete their PhD in the near future and one person is now a postdoctoral associate at another institution. In addition, Professor Chris Cramer served as an instructor for a summer workshop of the NSF supported Molecular Sciences Software Institute (MolSSI). In his presentation, he used pedagogical materials, distributed to the participants, that were informed by thermodynamics work aligned with the research activities of the sponsored project. For his undergraduate class on inorganic chemistry, Professor Gladfelter developed lessons on the use of inorganic and organometallic precursors used in vapor deposition processes. Under the leadership of Professor Bharat Jalan the undergraduate students in the Department of Chemical Engineering and Materials Science established a student chapter of the American Vacuum Society.

Scientific details resulting from this program can be found in the publications listed below.

T. Wang, K. C. Pitike, Y. Yuan, S. M. Nakhmanson, V. Gopalan and B. Jalan, Chemistry, Growth Kinetics and Epitaxial Stabilization of Sn2+ in Sn-doped SrTiO3 using (CH3)6Sn2 tin precursor, APL Mat. 4, 126111, (2016). DOI: 10.1063/1.4972995

T. Wang, L. R. Thoutam, A. Prakash, W. Nunn, G. Haugstad, B. Jalan (2017). Defect driven localization crossovers in MBE grown La-doped SrSnO3 films.. Phys. Rev. Mater. 1 061601. DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevMaterials.1.061601

Wang, T. Q.; Prakash, A.; Dong, Y. Q.; Truttmann, T.; Bucsek, A.; James, R.; Fong, D. D.; Kim, J. W.; Ryan, P. J.; Zhou, H.; Birol, T.; Jalan, B. Engineering SrSnO3 Phases and Electron Mobility at Room Temperature Using Epitaxial Strain ACS Appl. Mater. Inter. 2018, 10, 43802. DOI: 10.1021/acsami.8b16592

Harkins, R. P.; Cramer, C. J.; Gladfelter, W. L. "Computational Thermochemistry of Mono- and Dinuclear Tin Alkyls Used in Vapor Deposition Processes" J. Phys. Chem. A 2019, 123, 1451. DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpca.8b12072

Abhinav Prakash and Bharat Jalan, Molecular beam epitaxy for oxide electronics. In: Molecular Beam Epitaxy: Materials and Applications for Electronics and Optoelectronics (ed. Hajime Asahi and Yoshiji Horikoshi), John Wiley & Sons, 423 - 452 (2019). DOI: 10.1002/9781119354987.ch26

J. Yue, L. R. Thoutam A. Prakash, T. Wang, and B. Jalan (2019). Unravelling the effect of electron-electron interaction on electronic transport in high-mobility stannate films.  Appl. Phys. Lett.. 115  082102. DOI: 10.1063/1.5113522

Prakash, A.; Wang, T.; Choudhary, R.; Haugstad, G.; Gladfelter, W. L.; Jalan, B. (2020). Precursor Selection in Hybrid Molecular Beam Epitaxy of Alkaline-Earth Stannates.  J. Vac. Sci. Technol. A. 38  063410. DOI: 10.1116/6.0000590
